text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text on the right margin; full-width miniature to the left occupying the main block; a historiated ornamental initial “S” in red and burnished gold at the start of the text. The illustration is framed by a thin red line and shows three linked episodes under arcades, clearly separate from the text block but aligned horizontally with the first lines.

text_content.script_style: Gothic bastarda, professional book hand with consistent stroke width, frequent use of ligatures and abbreviations

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for framing and the ornamental initial, signifying importance. Ultramarine dresses mark principal figures; vermilion highlights garments and architectural details. Leaf green appears in backgrounds and drapery linings. White is used for flesh highlights and the bed linens. Colors are applied in thin, even layers with subtle white highlighting on robes and faces; original saturation remains high with minimal pigment darkening.

features: Three narrative episodes arranged left to right under arcade structure
Continuous floor tile motif unites the foreground across all scenes
Central small building façade creates a transitional divider
Figures overlap slightly to suggest depth
Architecture acts as framing device for each episode

decorative_elements: Thin red fillet border around miniature
Arcaded niches with roundels in archivolts
Historiated initial in burnished gold and red
Star-patterned blue background in bedchamber scene
Gilded capitals and column shafts dividing episodes

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill-pen outlines in dark brown ink with consistent weight, subtle modulations for facial features and drapery edges
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with white highlights on robes and flesh; minimal parallel hatching in shadows of folds
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: No true linear perspective; floor tiles recede via diminishing scale, architecture stacked vertically; figure sizes uniform according to narrative importance rather than spatial realism

reading_order: Left: Betrothal ceremony under church arch
Center: Sprinkling of holy water blessing beneath small façade

scene_relationships.subject: Bride and groom joined by priest at altar
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to formal blessing of the newly wedded couple
visual_connections: Ultramarine robe of the groom echoed in priest’s cope in next scene
Column capital shape continues from left to center niche
Red stole of priest reflected in red sleeves of central bride
Arch motif repeated in each niche
Floor tile pattern is continuous beneath figures

scene_relationships.subject: Priest in blue cope sprinkles holy water on bride
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Transitions to the consummation in the bridal chamber behind
visual_connections: Vertical align of priest’s raised hand points toward bed scene
Gold stripe on cope picks up gold stars in bed alcove
Grey dress of bride on the right echoes shadowed folds of left bride’s red gown
Architectural façade links centre to bedchamber opening
Continuous floor tiling leads viewer’s eye back

scene_relationships.subject: Consummation: groom lifts bride’s chemise on canopied bed
visual_connections: Blue starry canopy matches ultramarine garments in foreground
Gold canopy fringe echoes gold leaf frames
Raised arm gesture akin to priest’s in center scene
White bed linens connect to white highlights on figures
Diagonal composition of bed contrasts with vertical niches yet uses same palette

visual_continuity: Arcaded framing repeated across three episodes
Ultramarine and vermilion robes on principal figures
Gilded architectural details in capitals and border
Consistent figure scale and frontal postures

content_theme.scene_description: A three-part secular narrative depicting a noble marriage ritual and consummation. In the left arcade, the groom, clad in a long ultramarine houppelande with gold trim, and the bride, in a red fitted gown with narrow sleeves and gold edging, stand facing each other, hands clasped. Between them a priest in white alb and red stole officiates before a small altar draped in red, white and blue. The tiled floor in pale grey unites the scene. The central vignette shows the bride, now in a grey-violet gown, receiving a blessing from a priest in a blue and gold-striped cope who sprinkles holy water from an aspergillum; behind them rises a small pale façade. In the background, through an open arch, the groom in red and white linen raises the bride’s chemise on a bed with a blue star-spangled canopy. The composition uses overlapping niches to suggest depth. Figures are uniformly scaled, their garments painted in flat layers with white highlights. Each episode is set within a round-arched arcade, its carved ring-mouldings echoing throughout. The central action is the marital bond, supported by the blessing and consummation. The decorative gold framing, starry canopy, and repetition of red and blue establish visual harmony and narrative progression.

religious: Priest in white alb and red stole (betrothal ceremony)
Priest in blue and gold cope with aspergillum (blessing)
secular: Groom in ultramarine houppelande with gold trim (betrothal)
Bride in red gown with gold border (betrothal)

objects: Altar draped in red, white and blue cloth
Canopied bridal bed with star-patterned canopy
architectural: Small façade dividing left and central scenes

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, extremely smooth surface with visible plummet ruling; regular quaternion gathering, margins approx. 3 cm.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments are vivid with minimal darkening; slight flaking of lead white in floor tiles; gold leaf remains largely intact; very minor corner cockling.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in initial and framing
Visible underdrawing in iron-gal ink beneath color layers
Regular plummet ruling for text and floor pattern
Careful scraping and pumicing indicated by uniform parchment surface

secondary_functions: memory aid for courtly marital etiquette

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This richly illuminated page likely derives from a late 14th-century French courtly manuscript, possibly an illustrated romance or matrimonial treatise. The three-scene sequence—betrothal, blessing, and consummation—depicts the stages of medieval marriage with both secular and sacramental overtones. The precision of the Gothic bastarda script and the lavish use of ultramarine and gold suggest production in a well-endowed Parisian atelier. The style recalls the tail end of the so-called Second School of Paris, with its elegant figure types and refined architectural framing. The miniature’s emphasis on ceremony and domestic intimacy reflects contemporary courtly ideals and the growing vogue for private devotional and didactic books that combined moral instruction with romantic narrative. Technically, the use of gesso-raised gold and subtle underdrawing points to a high-end workshop practice, while the consistent tile pattern and harmonious color palette demonstrate a coherent artistic program. Iconographically, the progression from public ritual to private consummation underscores the dual nature of marriage as both civil contract and corporal union. The page stands in dialogue with other late medieval illuminations of sacramental themes—such as those in the Tales of Troy or the Roman de la Rose—yet distinguishes itself by integrating the bridal chamber scene, a motif more common in vernacular romances. As such, it exemplifies the fusion of secular narrative and religious ritual in the manuscripts of aristocratic patrons, bridging personal entertainment and moral reflection.
